results.justification: The paper explicitly states its methodology: "Following the coding process used by [28] (p. 306) the two authors discussed (1) how each one would approach the deductive and inductive analysis..." and details the deductive and inductive coding process.

The paper provides a detailed step-by-step description of the study design, including data collection, coding, inter-rater reliability assessment, and thematic analysis. See section 'In line with the purpose of this article...'
The paper provides a link to the working sheets: "We have also made available the working sheets in this link: https://kortlink.dk/2qx3t"

The raw data (the full papers from LAK conferences) are not publicly available, but this is inherent to the nature of the study and not a lack of transparency. The authors used publicly available conference proceedings.
The coding heuristic is described in detail, and the process of refining it is explained. The paper also details the categories used for analysis.

The data collection methods are fully described, including the selection criteria for papers (full papers from LAK '22, '23, and '24) and the exclusion criteria (systematic reviews, conceptual research, etc.).
The paper does not mention sharing the code used for the analysis (e.g., coding software, statistical packages).
The paper does not mention sharing code for data preparation.

The paper reports Fleiss’ kappa to assess agreement between the authors, a statistical measure. "The final kappa when comparing the results of the coding authors indicated a good level of agreement (^ = 0.76, subjects=154, raters= 2, and p <0.005)"
The analysis is primarily descriptive and categorical, focusing on frequencies and themes rather than statistical inference with effect sizes or confidence intervals.

The paper uses thematic analysis to identify patterns and insights from the literature, providing subjective context and interpretation. "The second part of the analysis involved an inductive coding of the limitations’ sections of articles in the corpus in order to develop a thematic analysis of pointers for increasing the generalisability of LA research."

The data coding process is clearly described, including the development and refinement of the coding heuristic, and the inter-rater reliability assessment. The authors also mention colour coding instances where they were unsure.
The results are clearly presented in Table 1, summarizing the categorization of the papers, and in Table 2, outlining the themes extracted from the analysis.

The paper includes a 'Limitations' section that discusses the scope of the analysis, potential biases, and the impact of the selection criteria. "Our paper on examining the lack of generalisability in LA has certain limitations..."
The paper does not mention or link to any preregistration.
